choices.D: It addresses the static architecture of traditional networks being decentralized and complex.
choices.A: It provides a programmatic and standards-based way of writing configurations to any network device.
choices.C: It simplifies management and operations by decoupling the networking hardware from its control mechanism.
choices.B: By modeling data, it ensures that vast quantities of data are usable for monitoring.

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of model-driven programmability?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Very obvious its A

Selected Answer: A
It's A

Selected Answer: A
Traditionally CLIs or SDK library functions are used to configure network devices. CLIs and scripts are almost always device-specific; they can only be used in the same type of devices that use the same CLis from the same vendor. Moreover, those functions may not exist for all configuration commands, and where they do exist, it may be difficult to program a complex configuration. 

So, the correct answer is A since the model-driven programming provides a standard way to describe the desired configuration of the network devices. Of course, the target device itself has to support the ability to use model-driven configuration.
I think it's D

questions.question_text: Which type of HTTP method is used by the Meraki and Webex Teams APIs to send webhook notifications?

discussion.content:
A. HTTP POST

https://developer.webex.com/docs/api/guides/webhooks

A webhook is an HTTP callback, or an HTTP POST, to a specified URL that notifies your app when a particular activity or “event” has occurred in one of your resources on the Webex Teams platform.
A is right

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The Cisco Meraki API manages two organizations. In each organization, two independent networks are defined. How many calls to the / organizations/{orgId}/networks endpoint will be run parallel by the GetAllNetworks function of the API client?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
At first glance it looks like D, but I think it's C because it loops with {orgId} as a variable.

Selected Answer: C
Answer: C. 2
Explanation:

 The Cisco Meraki API manages two organizations.
 Each organization has two independent networks.
 The GetAllNetworks function retrieves networks by calling:

/organizations/{orgId}/networks

This endpoint returns all networks within a specific organization.
The diagram shows that GetAllNetworks loops over each organization ID (orgId), meaning one API call per organization.
Since there are two organizations, the API will make two calls to /organizations/{orgId}/networks.

Selected Answer: B
I would pick B.
There are 2 calls in total, one for each organization to get all networks for that org. The number of networks itself doesn't matter (unless you run into pagination which the default is 1000 networks).
These 2 calls are done sequentially and synchronously (solid arrowhead) in a loop.
So 2 calls in total, 1 at a time.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. There are 2 organizations, each has 2 networks. The calls are being made to "organizations" (probably getting a list of networks for each org), not to "networks" directly.
The loop is iterating per "orgId", so there will be 2 calls in total, each call will be done when the previous one finishes. The answer: 1 call will be run in parallel by the GetAllNetworks function - option B.

solid arrow head and arrow with dotted line indicate a synchronous call and synchronous response. synchronous operations are blocking and only one can run at a time, meaning that the answer is B, 1 at a time

comments.content: all though at this point we are into semantics, is 1 operation a time 0 parallel operations or 1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The GetAllNetworks function of the API client will run four calls to the /organizations/{orgId}/networks endpoint in parallel. There are two organizations defined, and each organization has two independent networks defined. Therefore, four calls will be run in parallel to retrieve the networks for both organizations.

Selected Answer: C
It should be 2 for the 2 networks.
The organizations are handled in sequence 1 at the time
Why not A? loop is a sequential way not a parallel way

comments.content: This is my thought as well. It doesn't seem like any parallel operations should be happening. It iterates once per orgId. It doesn't call the API for both of them at the same time.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It's C, because the question mentions orgId in the URI

But "PUT can create a resource, but PATCH cannot"
https://josipmisko.com/posts/patch-vs-put-rest-api

Selected Answer: B
B is the most logical

Selected Answer: B
204 is a success code.
PATCH method is used.
B is the most logical

choices.B: The query updated the logging severity level or created it if not present on the device.
choices.D: The query failed to set the logging severity level due to an invalid path.
choices.A: The query retrieved the logging severity level.
choices.C: The query failed at retrieving the logging severity level.

questions.question_text: What is a requirement when authenticating a RESTCONF API session with a router that runs Cisco IOS XE Software?

comments.content: On a second thought, C might be correct too - it describes the same mechanism, I would say C is "more correct" than D
The question mentions "a requirement when authenticating restconf api SESSION", so for establishing the session, basic authentication is used. D is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct - first there's basic authentication, then a token is used for follow-up interaction. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/csr1000/software/restapi/restapi/RESTAPIclient.html

C is the correct response.
A post needs to be done to get the token, then it's added in the header
To get this token, we need to send the basic auth.

Selected Answer: D
D.
From the book: "Authentication is accomplished using typical HTTP authentication models, such as basic authentication, where usernames and passwords are Base64 encoded and transmitted from the client to the server via an Authentication header"

choices.C: A token must be retrieved and the associated string must be embedded in the X-Auth-Token header.
